thread.title: Australian corporate bonds calm amid Asian storm
thread.title_full: Australian corporate bonds calm amid Asian storm | afr.com

author: Vanessa Desloires
title: Australian corporate bonds calm amid Asian storm
text:
Corporate bond spreads have remained calm while US and UK spreads have spiked Jessica Shapiro Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Vanessa Desloires Australian bonds have been a source of zen for investors amid the storm that has enveloped global markets over the past month.
Corporate bonds have delivered modest yet positive returns throughout August while equities have plummeted by 8 per cent, and have been less susceptible to the global volatility that has encroached on almost all asset classes, according to Spectrum Asset Management.
Spectrum principal Damien Wood said at first glance it seemed odd that Australia's credit markets had outperformed global peers.
"Given Australia's economic link with China, one would expect Australian credit fundamentals to be more at risk than those in the US and the UK," he said.
Australian bonds have been steady in August Spectrum Asset Management But Australia's long-term, highly dependent relationship with China could mean investors had a better understanding of China's economics and policy compared with credit investors outside Asia, Mr Wood said.
"It is possible that credit investors were comfortable with the situation in China," he said.
"All the concerns about China are valid, but were they in a western democracy with an open capital account, then there would be large causes for concern."
Australian BBB or medium quality bond credit spreads, have remained steady compared with the US and UK which have spiked over the past month. When bond spreads spike the market is factoring in a higher risk.
 "Credit spreads have been blowing out, but it is quite unusual that two months ago Australia looked cheap compared to the rest of the world and we are now looking expensive," Mr Wood said.
"This is different to the global financial crisis (GFC) when everything was sold off."
Nikko Asset Management global rates and currency strategist Roger Bridges said the relatively limited supply of Australian bonds has shielded them from the volatility.
"The amount of corporate debt is reducing, during the GFC we had 30 per cent corporate paper while nowadays it is down to something like 15 per cent," Mr Bridges said.
"We are seeing a lack of credit â€” that's why the Apple deal went so well."
The US technology giant last week printed $2.25 billion in Australian dollar bonds, smashing the record for the largest corporate bond issue in Australia.
The corporate debt conditions were starkly different to the US, where companies have been borrowing heavily to launch share buybacks and pay dividends, as well as protect their offshore earnings as a surging US dollar has mad the exchange rate more expensive, Mr Bridges said.
Australian companies are being viewed as attractive relative to the instability in Asian markets.
Goldman Sachs this week moved into high-yielding Australian equities whose reliable dividends stood out among collapsing Asian equity and currency markets.
Mr Wood said Australian corporate bonds were likely to deliver steady returns over the next 12 months because he believed China's government had policy tools available to avoid a sharp slowdown in its economic growth.
"This in turn assists Australia's economic growth outlook and reduces the chances of a jump in Australian default rates," Mr Wood said.
